body: cc @DaiMichael - appreciate this has been a long running issue, however your help in figuring this one out would be much appreciated! ðŸ˜„

From the commit:

Not any more. I corrected the errors, and all of the DictionaryContainsKeyConstraintTests now pass.

With the errors, many of the DictionaryContainsKeyConstraintTests test failed.

I was debugging that failures and saw these routines fail in the debugger.

This is why I am very confused as to how the tests pass for everyone else.

Unless, in the regular .NET environment, those two routines are never being called? Remember, I am running the tests in the CF environment. Not sure why it would be different.

Can someone see if they are ever actually called in regular .NET?

Remember that generics are handled totally differently in CF then they are in regular .NET.
It is not the return that is the error.  It is the comparison.  The returns are correct if the comparison is corrected.
@ChrisMaddock @oznetmaster I'll take a look, I'll be honest neither myself nor @jnm2 were 100% happy with this solution but it "worked" or so it seemed.... I'll revisit.

@ChrisMaddock @oznetmaster 

I'm going with a PR on this so you guys can take a peek. I've got it working, this is purely for `.Net Standard 1.4`, which I'm growing to err... finding lack of features hard work.... ðŸ˜ž 

My tests all work and I now understand why they all work ðŸ˜†, I won't pretend it is the best thing in the world but I have spent quite a bit of time on this and this is the only solution I got working with no side effects and passes all the tests.

I'll add a comment in the PR about the method...

issue.title: Error in .NET Standard 1.4 DictionaryContainsKeyConstraint MetadataToken compatibility methods
issue.body:
@ChrisMaddock @oznetmaster 
As per the #2994 comments.

I've gone with a signature matching routine. Remember this is for `.NET Standard 1.4` only, I'm hoping the use case is low, I'm expecting the users in the "wild" is low and most people would be using > 1.6, I can but hope.

As per C# specification... I've been looking... basically a signature to be unique needs to be method name and parameter combination. Doesn't even need to worry about return type as you can't overload. 

In this instance we know we are trying to match 
- `Contains` method.
- Return type will always be `bool`, or same for all instances of the method.
- Generic type with name `TKey`.

So the signature matches against all the methods of the main type with the filtered list. We know the above points. So I basically try to construct the signature matching the method with those types. 

`TKey` is hard coded as per all code paths.
Parameter Name (usually `key`) is matched as per the method, this will allow us to match if the user changes the parameter name when overriding.

Am I loving it... hmm... I'll go with it works and it is probably better than the last code. We could just support `1.6 ` upwards and this would go away ðŸ˜ƒ 

Debuging against `.NetCore` is hard work..... 

Fixes #2994
